thread.title: Indonesian volcano Mount Raung leaves 1000s stranded as Bali airports close
thread.title_full: Indonesian volcano Mount Raung leaves 1000s stranded as Bali airports close | Daily Mail Online

author: Afp
title: Indonesian volcano Mount Raung leaves 1000s stranded as Bali airports close
text:
20 shares 2
View
comments
Thousands of holidaymakers have been left frustrated and stranded in Bali after ash from an Indonesian volcano caused around 250 flights to be cancelled.
Indonesian authorities shut five airports today in response to Mount Raung in the East Java province spewing clouds of ash.
Many major airlines including AirAsia, Virgin Australia and Jetstar and Air New Zealand have cancelled flights in and out of the island.
The closures came during peak holiday season in Bali, a pocket of Hinduism in Muslim-majority Indonesia which attracts millions of foreign tourists every year to its palm-fringed beaches.
Thousands of holidaymakers have been left stranded in Bali after ash from an Indonesian volcano has caused around 250 flights to be cancelled
Foreign tourists face severe delays and cancelled flights at Ngurah Rai International airport
Stranded passengers wait for information following AirAsia, Virgin Australia and Jetstar, and Air New Zealand confirming flights to Bali have been cancelled
Indonesian airports close due to volcanic eruption in Bali 'It's pretty chaotic,' Katie Nagar, an American expatriate living in Indonesia told AFP.
She described arriving at the domestic terminal in Bali's Ngurah Rai airport to discover her flight on Indonesian flag carrier Garuda to Jakarta had been cancelled and rescheduled to Sunday.
'There's basically just hundreds of people camped out on the grassy lawns in front of the airport. There's lines of hundreds of people waiting to talk to customer service.'
Frustrated passengers took to Twitter to express their frustration.
User Dawie Aker said: 'Family of four stuck in Bali - no Jetstar response by phone and this bizarre message on the web.'
While @maddysure said: 'Stuck in Bali for another fortnight? Is this a joke?? I have an internship, a dog and a life to get back to @JetstarAirways.'
So far 250 flights have been cancelled due to the chaos caused by the ash cloud
Indonesian authorities shut five airports today in response to Mount Raung in the East Java province spewing clouds of ash
An AFP reporter in the international terminal estimated about 1,000 people were stranded there, with some trying to seek out information from airport officials while others were sitting or sleeping on the floor.
Trikora Harjo, general manager at Ngurah Rai, confirmed that hundreds of domestic and international flights - had so far been cancelled at the airport due to the ash cloud.
'Right now the authorities have declared that the airport will be closed until 9:30 pm (1330 GMT), totally closed,' he said.
 Next Volcanic ash cloud continues to cause havoc over Bali as... School holiday chaos continues as Virgin and Jetstar flights... Tasmania's stunning landscape and wildlife have seen it... Meet the real-life Indiana Jane: American adventurer spends... 20 shares Foreign tourists sit in front of a cafe awaiting further news on their rescheduled flights
The volcano ash has caused chaos for holidaymakers as airports close and international airlines
Authorities raised the alert status of Mount Raung, a 10,800 ft volcano, late last month to the second highest level after it began to spew lava and ash high into the air
Authorities said that no evacuations were necessary as those living in the area were already a safe distance away.
Other airports closed by the ash included a second, smaller one on Lombok and two in East Java serving domestic routes
Jetstar was amongst those who grounded its services and asked passengers to contact them for further information
Garuda confirmed on its Twitter account that it had cancelled a total of 112 flights on Friday. Most were to and from Bali airport, but 18 were to other airports affected by the ash cloud.
AirAsia, Virgin Australia and Jetstar, and Air New Zealand also confirmed flights to Bali had been cancelled.
In a statement released by Virgin this morning, the airline said: 'Due to the impact of the volcanic eruption at Mt Raung, Virgin Australia has cancelled all flights in and out of Denpasar (Bali) today (10 July).'
Virgin continued: 'Once conditions improve, additional flights will be scheduled between Australia and Denpasar to ensure we can have guests on their way as soon as possible.'
A spokesperson for Air New Zealand said: 'We apologise for the inconvenience to passengers, however, the ash conditions are outside Air New Zealand's safety parameters and we're unable to operate until the situation improves'.
PREVIOUS EPISODES OF VOLCANIC ACTIVITY DISRUPTING FLIGHTS Smoke and ash rise from the Calbuco volcano, south of Santiago in Chile, causing numerous flights to be cancelled in April 2015
In May an ash cloud from the volcanic eruption of Mount Sangeang Api in Indonesia played havoc with Australia's flight paths.
Darwin remained cut off to all air services and thousands of people were left stranded in the city after the ash cloud blew over the Northern Territory coast line, forcing the airport to close.
Flights from Darwin remained cancelled for a couple of days.
A similar event had occurred in the previous month, when an ash cloud from the Calbuco volcano in southern Chile erupted unexpectedly forcing the cancellation of flights from nearby cities in both countries and blanketing residents in ash.
Virgin Australia said in a statement that 'our team of meteorologists continue to work closely with the Volcanic Ash Advisory Centre in Darwin and monitor the situation
Indonesian government vulcanologist Surono, who like many Indonesians goes by one name, said eruptions were continuing at the volcano Friday, and it was producing flames and a thundering sound
Authorities raised the alert status of Mount Raung, a 10,800 ft volcano, late last month to the second highest level after it began to spew lava and ash high into the air.
Indonesian government vulcanologist Surono, who like many Indonesians goes by one name, said eruptions were continuing at the volcano Friday, and it was producing flames and a thundering sound.
WHAT HAPPENS IF VOLCANIC ASH GETS IN A PLANE ENGINE? 'Volcanic ash is kind of like grit or sandpaper,' said John Hansman, a professor of Aeronautics and Astronautics at MIT, as reported by AccuWeather .
'If it goes into the engines and is the right size, it can cause the engines to shut down.'
He said if when ash is sucked into the engines, it is melted by the heat of the engine.The melted ash then coats the inside of the engine, ultimately leading to engine failure.
Another cause concern is the fact volcanic ash is actually highly abrasive and can scratch and erode plastic, glass and metals.
If the cockpit windows become scratched, pilots can have increasing difficulty seeing the runways and landing the plane safely.
But authorities said that no evacuations were necessary as those living in the area were already a safe distance away.
Virgin Australia said in a statement that 'our team of meteorologists continue to work closely with the Volcanic Ash Advisory Centre in Darwin and monitor the situation.
'Once conditions improve, additional flights will be scheduled between Australia and Denpasar to ensure we can have guests on their way as soon as possible.'
Jetstar also grounded its services and asked passengers to contact them for further information.
The two Australian carriers had already cancelled flights in and out of Bali in recent days due to the volcanic ash, even before the airport was fully closed.
Air New Zealand said that a flight due to depart from Bali on Saturday afternoon had been rescheduled to leave early Sunday, conditions permitting.
Other airports closed by the ash included a second, smaller one on Lombok and two in East Java serving domestic routes.
Indonesia sits on the Pacific Ring of Fire, a belt of seismic activity running around the basin of the Pacific Ocean, and has around 130 active volcanoes.
Indonesia sits on the Pacific Ring of Fire, a belt of seismic activity running around the basin of the Pacific Ocean, and has around 130 active volcanoes
